image.altText: A man in a hat and flannelette shirt on a khaki-coloured all-terrain vehicle.

props.synopsis: Neighbouring landholders of a private hydro-electric scheme in north-west Tasmania fear what will happen if it begins pumping again, after it was paused last year to investigate potential flooding.

title.children: Farmer buys amphibious, eight-wheeled vehicle after he says nearby hydro scheme flooded his property

image.altText: Hands clasping at prison cell bars, good generic for prison, detention, jail, confinement

props.synopsis: If millions of taxpayers' dollars, wrecked lives and "harrowing" stories of abuse aren't enough to speed up the closure of Tasmania's notorious Ashley youth prison, then what is?

title.children: Tasmania will pay $75m to kids whose lives were ruined at a prison which is still open, despite years of promises to shut it

image.altText: Reid Ludwig died after a stabbing incident

props.synopsis: Since her son's death in a stabbing attack in 2019, Laraine Ludwig has campaigned for tougher knife laws in Tasmania. Now, with a trial for police to be able to search for weapons about to begin, she hopes no other family will go through what her's did.

title.children: Mum of stabbing victim hoping Reid's Law will help to stop Tasmanians carrying concealed knives

image.altText: Two red and white ships break through an icy body of water.

props.synopsis: The icebreakers have been invited to expand their use of Hobart as part of a push by the Tasmanian government to capitalise on China's growing interest in Antarctica.

title.children: Tasmania invites Chinese icebreakers to expand their use of Hobart as gateway city to Antarctica

image.altText: A man between large rocks in a river holds on to one end of a yellow rope

props.synopsis: A rescue team faced with a terrible decision, complicated by a language barrier and unthinkable challenges, such as 13 tonnes of water per second to deal with. How did they save a man trapped for more than 20 hours in a river?

title.children: 'No-one's practised amputating a leg in the middle of a river': How rescuers freed a man trapped while whitewater rafting

image.altText: A woman is pushing a child on a swing, she has a child on her back and a third child is on a second swing

props.synopsis: Parents in this island community, which has no child care services, were "very excited" when an early learning trial for three-year-olds was promised by 2024. Now, with no progress made on delivering that, parents want answers.

title.children: Did you miss? 📣 On this island there's no childcare and a promised early learning initiative is behind schedule

image.altText: a woman is sitting at a table looking at a utility bill.

props.synopsis: With so many technological advances, why does it feel like we spend more time doing paperwork than ever before? And who is profiting from all the virtual paper shuffling?

title.children: Businesses are now trying to sell everything 'as a service' and you're paying with your time

image.altText: Teen girl with curly hair and tan skin looks down at her phone wearing a stripy jumper. There are social media icons next to her

props.synopsis: Yesterday, parliament heard that the major parties will come together and pass a law banning teenagers from social media, after a period of careful thought roughly commensurate with that of a 15-year-old making a Black Friday impulse buy at Shein.com.

title.children: Parliament delivers a performance piece of legislative 'enshittification' that raises more questions than answers

image.altText: An illustration of a gymnast looking at their phone.

props.synopsis: A gymnastics coach who quit the Australian Olympic team after the ABC revealed he allegedly harassed a former colleague is now being accused of making sexual comments to his former teenage athletes.

title.children: 'He used to name our bums': Melbourne gymnastics coach who withdrew from Paris Olympics facing more allegations

image.altText: Two men talking to media.

props.synopsis: The bodies of two Melbourne teenagers who died after suspected methanol poisoning in Laos return home, as Laos police investigating their deaths detain eight men.

title.children: 'We miss our daughters desperately': Families of Bianca Jones and Holly Bowles welcome Laos arrests

image.altText: Tanya Plibersek holds a python at Parliament House

props.synopsis: After an intense day on Tuesday of last-minute negotiations and lobbying by environmental and mining groups in which a deal was said to have "come close", the government has now shelved the talks.

title.children: Environmental protection laws appear doomed after deal with Greens fizzles

image.altText: Finances generic

props.synopsis: Australia's annual inflation rate remained steady in October at a more than three-year low as electricity and fuel prices fell. The local share market is trading higher after a rally on Wall Street. Follow the day's trade on the live markets blog.

title.children: ASX rises as inflation rate stays steady, Bitcoin falls to a one-week low

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: New Zealand cuts interest rates, flags further cuts ahead
Inflation steady in October, at lowest annual rate since July 2021: ABS
Trimmed mean inflation rises to 3.5 per cent in October

image.altText: A man wearing a suit looking sideways with his lips pursed

props.synopsis: The climate change minister will present the latest annual scorecard from his department to parliament on Thursday.

title.children: Bowen declares mission accomplished on 2030 emissions as 2035 row heats up

image.altText: A man with short dark hair looks solemn as he stands outdoors.

props.synopsis: Not only did thieves steal Drew Cameron's vehicle twice in the space of a few nights, they also tracked his movements and knocked out his home security system.

title.children: Tech-savvy crooks steal man's BMW twice as Victoria registers alarming spike in car thefts

image.altText: A young white toddler reads a book with her mother by a kitchen window

props.synopsis: The Inclusion Support Program aims to help early learning centres remove barriers that prevent them from including students with disability. But childcare workers have told the ABC they're having problems accessing the scheme.

title.children: 'Absolutely furious, bewildered, and sad': Families say multi-million-dollar 'inclusion' program is excluding their kids

image.altText: An anonymous outline of a woman with signs from the Hidden Valley community in the background.

props.synopsis: Eight more Aboriginal women in the Northern Territory are dead this year with barely been a pip in parliament or national media. Have we become desensitised to the violence?

title.children: The Northern Territory's 'unrelenting horror' of violence against women is our national shame

image.altText: A man in front of Chinese flag.

props.synopsis: The Chinese ambassador to New Zealand, Wang Xiaolong, says if New Zealand joins security grouping AUKUS it will "inevitably" have negative consequences for the country's relationship with China.

title.children: China warns New Zealand against joining AUKUS

image.altText: Sun shines against power pole in NSW.

props.synopsis: NSW Premier Chris Minns asks businesses and homes to reduce energy use between 3pm and 8pm this evening as large-scale power shortages are expected across the state.

title.children: NSW premier urges people to reduce energy use today as power shortages expected amid heatwave

image.altText: A wide v shaped line that looks bull dozed into a shrubby desert landscape from an aerial view.

props.synopsis: The origin of the strange clearing, which is still visible today, was detected by a scientist trawling through satellite data.

title.children: A tornado tore across the Nullarbor but we're only just learning about it now

image.altText: Black and white 'for rent' sign

props.synopsis: More than 20 per cent of Australian renters are living in poverty after their rent has been paid, a new study has found.

title.children: Struggling Australians being forced into poverty with 'nowhere affordable to live'

image.altText: Alec at Palm Island

props.synopsis: On the short ferry ride from Townsville to Palm Island, Alec Doomadgee prepared himself for cultural work marking the 20th anniversary of his brother's death.

title.children: 'They are forgiving what happened': Twenty years on from the 'horrific' death that sparked unrest and riots on Palm Island

image.altText: A young woman with a plastic bandage over her eye

props.synopsis: Ranem Abu Izneid fears her dreams of becoming a dentist are over after she was hit with shrapnel while studying in her university accommodation in the West Bank.

title.children: Melbourne woman demands answers after losing vision in alleged Israeli military shooting

image.altText: A man in profile, wearing a suit.

props.synopsis: Sweeping new powers to deport non-citizens are set to pass the parliament after Coalition members of a Senate committee voiced their support.

title.children: Sweeping powers to force deportations set to pass with bipartisan support

image.altText: An excavator works on a sinkhole on the Great Alpine road.

props.synopsis: Specialist crews have "peeled back" a section of the Great Alpine Road to reveal a 6-metre-deep pit.

title.children: Road workers uncover depths of 'giant' sinkhole in Victoria's Alps

image.altText: Air Asia X plane close up

props.synopsis: A deal which would have brought more international flights to the Northern Territory has fallen through, with Darwin Airport blaming its ongoing major runway works.

title.children: Darwin Airport blames runway works for Air Asia deal falling over

image.altText: Australian cricket coach Darren Lehmann, in a blue shirt, claps to honour remembrance of Phil Hughes on screen at Adelaide Oval.

props.synopsis: In 2014, Darren Lehmann answered the phone with news that would bear one of the most tragic moments in Australian sport. In a time when Australia is now searching for a Test opener, Phil Hughes should have been entering the twilight of his Test career. 10 years on from Hughes' death, it still hits home for many in the cricket world.

title.children: 'He would've just gone from strength to strength': Lehmann's emotional tribute to Hughes a decade on from his tragic death

image.altText: Students sit at desks completing their exam on lap tops.

props.synopsis: The body overseeing VCE exams in Victoria says it has identified 56 subjects potentially affected by an error that may have given some students an advantage.

title.children: More than 50 subjects potentially affected by Victorian school exam blunder

image.altText: A praying mantis insect standing on top of a parcel box.

props.synopsis: Owners of a Queensland business say they were overcharged dozens of times by an automated system, including being charged more than $700 for a single 300-gram parcel.

title.children: Business owners uncover dozens of times they were overcharged by Australia Post

image.altText: Kids beneath a windmill at sunset.

props.synopsis: Carnarvon School of the Air students have shed light on what life is like in the outback in a special music video.

title.children: 'Pretty bloody special': Outback kids unite to put station life to music

image.altText: Bundy tobacconist

props.synopsis: Authorities have used new closure powers to shut down three Bundaberg retailers suspected of selling illegal "chop chop" tobacco and vapes as the laws are enforced in Queensland for the first time.

title.children: Queensland's tougher tobacco laws enforced for the first time as stores ordered to close for 72 hours

image.altText: A track cyclist wearing a British uniform looks to the stands with his finger raised in celebration after crossing the line.

props.synopsis: Matthew Richardson says AusCycling's lifetime ban on him is similar to an employer firing someone who has already resigned, but he says he hopes it will understand his defection to Team GB in time.

title.children: 'Just words on a piece of paper': Defector Richardson laughs off AusCycling life ban

image.altText: A man in a wide brimmed hat sits on a green eight wheeled vehicle, in a paddock.

props.synopsis: Neighbouring landholders of a private hydro-electric scheme in north-west Tasmania fear what will happen if it begins pumping again, after it was paused last year to investigate potential flooding.

title.children: Farmer buys amphibious, eight-wheeled vehicle after he says nearby hydro scheme flooded his property

image.altText: Evelyn Glennie performing a solo with an orchestra. She's holding two drum sticks and looking intently at her music score.

props.synopsis: Deaf artists Dame Evelyn Glennie and Raymond Antrobus are busting the myth that they live in a world of silence. A new album opens their sound world.

title.children: Artists are busting the myth that deaf people live in a world of silence
